attributes.alt: Book cover for Preschool Time by Mij Kely and Mary McQuillan. The cover is a drawing of a girl, a cow, a goose, a sheep, and a horse playing musical instruments, drawing, and having fun.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
Why do the animals go to the school?
Read for enjoyment and understanding, noticing vocabulary in context.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Identify own body within surroundings  and respect others’ personal space.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Challenge children to identify the different ways that we can reply to someone.
Encourage children to respond in complete sentences.
What do we do at school?
What are the children in the book doing? Are they at school?
Can you act like you’re searching for someone or something?
Can you draw two animals that are looking for Suzy Sue?
What school activities could you write about?
Can you draw something that you do every day at school?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to make a shelf for your book?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder  to
Read closely to notice and talk about the  Mind Builder.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Show self-awareness in different or multiple ways.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Challenge children to act out different words and sentences from
Encourage children to use complete sentences to accompany their pantomimes.
What do we do at school?
Can you show something you do at school?
Pretend you are a preschool teacher. What would you teach?
Name three things that you use at school.
What do you like to do at school? Can you write about it?
Draw a picture of something that you see in your classroom.
Can you name the first letter in the word
? Can you think of any words that start with that letter?
Can you build a preschool out  of blocks?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the comprehension skill
What do the animals learn about Suzy Sue’s preschool?
Check understanding and differentiate as needed.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Explore geography tools and resources, such as maps, signs, and street addresses.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Describe and sort objects by similarities and differences.
Have children divide picture cards into “pretend things” and “real things.”
Encourage children to use complete sentences in their speech.
What do we do at school?
How are the characters in the book the same? Different?
Pretend you are a character  in the book. Show how you  would act.
Look at the characters in the book. Which one is the biggest? How do you know?
Can you write about something  that you do every day at preschool?
How many real farm animals have you seen? Can you draw one and color it?
What letter makes the sound you hear at the beginning of the word
Can you use blocks to build  a farm?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Our School Rules. The rules show that we share, we clean up, we take turns, we listen, we stay safe, and we are kind.
Book cover for Preschool Time by Mij Kely and Mary McQuillan. The cover is a drawing of a girl, a cow, a goose, a sheep, and a horse playing musical instruments, drawing, and having fun.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build background on school rules, and introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to this week’s concept question,
What do we do at school?
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Master basic skills of running, jumping, climbing, and pedaling.
Have children divide picture cards into activities they do at school and activities they do not do at school.
Encourage children to use complete sentences in their conversation and responses.
What do we do at school?
What do you think Suzy Sue’s friends like about preschool? Why?
Pretend to play one of your favorite outdoor games.
Which preschool activities did Suzy Sue’s friends like the best?
did you like the most? Can you write about it?
Can you use clay or paper to make or draw the animal you liked the most in
Can you show me what letter makes the beginning of the word
? What sound does that letter make?
Can you build a wall out of blocks that you can jump over? Not too high!

attributes.alt: Book cover for Preschool Time by Mij Kely and Mary McQuillan. The cover is a drawing of a girl, a cow, a goose, a sheep, and a horse playing musical instruments, drawing, and having fun.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to have children act out animal characters and to introduce vocabulary words
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What do the animals do when they come home?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and imagination.
Respond appropriately to spoken language; Show understanding of spoken language.
Show an awareness of new words and curiosity about their meaning.
Use different art materials for exploration and for sensory experience.
Show emerging proficiency on tasks requiring eye-hand coordination (draw pictures recognizable to child but not others; cut with scissors but may not be able to cut across page.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
If you could make a disguise, what would it look like?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
What do we do at school?
If you wrote your own book about school, what would you put in it?
Can you pretend to be the dog searching high and low for  Suzy Sue?
Can you work together to name four farm animals? Which is the biggest? Which is the smallest?
Can you create a story about a group with farm animals?
The farm animals made a plan when they came home. Can you make a plan for your home?
Can you use blocks to build a school for Suzy Sue and her animal friends?

Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
